Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Effects of Habitat Heterogeneity on Songbird Fecundity in an Experimental Landscape
Award.AbstractNarration:
Landscape heterogeneity promotes higher biodiversity in natural ecosystems. In North America, tallgrass prairie was historically maintained as a mosaic of different habitats by the interaction between fire and selective grazing by large herbivores, including bison, elk and pronghorn. In recent decades, agricultural intensification has led to more homogeneous landscapes in managed grasslands, which has been linked to widespread declines in songbird populations in North America and Europe. A loss of heterogeneity in grasslands could have major consequences for birds by changing food availability, predation risk, or rates of brood parasitism by Brown-headed Cowbirds (Molothrus ater). The proposed field study will estimate the effects of habitat heterogeneity on movements and survival of juvenile Dickcissels (Spiza americana), a songbird of conservation concern. The project will provide a better understanding of the reproductive ecology of grassland songbirds in managed grasslands, and will aid in understanding the relationships among grassland management and ecology, bird populations, and conservation.

This field study will be conducted in the Flint Hills ecoregion of eastern Kansas and Oklahoma, where large tracts of native tallgrass prairie still remain, however habitat quality has been impacted by ongoing changes in rangeland management. Konza Prairie is an NSF-funded Long-term Ecological Research (LTER) site in the northern Flint Hills, and provides a unique experimental landscape with different levels of habitat heterogeneity created by long-term grazing and fire treatments. Patch-burn grazing management increases heterogeneity in vegetative structure because only a third of the pasture is burned each year in a three-year rotational scheme, and movements of grazing cattle are unrestricted. A fourth pasture with annual burns and season-long stocking of cattle will be a negative control, and a fifth pasture with annual burns but no grazing will be a positive control. The researchers will attach small radio-transmitters to a total of 60 fledglings, across the five experimental treatments. Fledglings will be re-located daily during the first 30 days after leaving the nest to determine movements and survival. The research will estimate fledgling movements, arthropod prey availability, and fledgling survival using field methods and statistical analyses. Understanding how biotic factors interact with demographic parameters like nest and fledgling survival will help to understand the role of landscape heterogeneity on the life-history strategies of birds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary – The goal of our field project was to test the effects of habitat heterogeneity on the reproductive success of Dickcissels (Spiza americana), a declining species of grassland songbird. Specifically, we examined food availability, predation risk and brood parasitism by Brown-headed Cowbirds (Molothrus ater) in a large-scale field experiment testing patch-burn grazing as a rotational tool for rangeland management. Our experimental design included three experimental units that formed one larger pasture that was managed with rotational fire and grazing by cattle in a patch-burn grazing management regime. One unit that was annually burned and had season-long cattle stocking served as a negative control, and another unit that was annually burned but not grazed served as a positive control. To study the population ecology of Dickcissels, we searched for nests to determine reproductive success, deployed small VHF radio-transmitters on Dickcissel fledglings to determine post-fledging survival and movements, and used bird remains to identify predators of fledglings. To link the reproductive success and space-use of Dickcissels to environmental variables, we conducted vegetation sampling and examined available invertebrate abundance in all treatments.

 

Intellectual Merit – Demographic models indicate that the survival and movements of fledglings is a crucial life history stage, but the fledgling phase of songbirds has been poorly studied. With our study, we provide some of the first estimates of fledgling survival for grassland songbirds. Survival of fledgling Dickcissels between leaving the nest and gaining independence from their parents was surprisingly high. Unexpectedly, birds tended to use shrub patches adjacent to nesting areas in the prairie, possibly to avoid predation. Robust estimates of fledgling survival are necessary for population models, especially in the light of the ongoing declines in population numbers of many species of grassland songbirds.

            In comparison to the relatively high estimates of fledgling survival, Dickcissel nest survival was extremely low in our study area (0.075 – 0.227, n = 354 nests). Interestingly, we found that fledgling survival was lowest in the pastures with the highest nest survival rates. As a result, our field data indicate a possible tradeoff between the nest and fledgling stage of Dickcissels, where management could be favorable for one life stage, but has negative consequences for the other. By estimating what drives the survival and movements of Dickcissel fledglings we now better understand how young time their departure from the nest.

            In our study, we found substantial directional movements of fledglings away from areas with heavy grass cover and deep litter layers. Most fledgling mortalities (4/7) were caused by snakes. Directional movement away from grass cover by fledglings could be an adaptation to avoid predation risk, as snakes are often more abundant in grasslands with high levels of cover and litter. In contrast, we did not find any relation between grasshopper abundance and fledgling survival, or observed any directional movements towards areas with high prey abundance, suggesting that survival and movements might be driven by predator avoidance instead of food availability.

 

Broader Impacts – Grassland songbirds, including Dickcissels, are facing some of the largest and most widespread population declines of any bird guild in North America. To halt ongoing population declines, we need to better understand how the environment affects the complete life-cycle of birds. Our study provides some of the first survival estimates for fledglings, a previously underappreciated but crucial part of the life cycle of grassland songbirds.

            Our field study was conducted at the Konza Prairie Biological Station, which is part of the NSF-funded Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) network. By adding to the extensive list of research that has originated from the Konza Prairie, we help to ensure the continuation of the long term data collection on this research site. Our study at Konza Prairie also provided a training opportunity for one PhD candidate, two Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) students, and one undergraduate research technician. Students received experience in monitoring environmental data, species identification of grassland birds, interpreting bird behavior, and live-handling birds. Both REU students obtained further experience in experimental design, data management and analysis, and oral presentation of scientific data.

            Finally, our project reached out to the general public via the Konza Environmental Education Program (KEEP), which hosts workshops for teachers, and research experiences for K-12 students. We have been directly involved with public educational events including Konza Workshops and the biennial Konza Prairie Visitors Day, where researchers interact with the general public and raise interest in the tallgrass prairie. Our research was conducted under federal and state permits for wildlife research, and research protocols were approved by institutional animal care and use committees at Kansas State University.
